Expectation1: Look out for each other's safety and well-being
Situation1: The siblings are walking home from school together on a familiar street.
Situation2: They spot a child struggling in the deep end where swimming is restricted.
Story: My little brother and I were walking home from school, chatting about our day, when we passed by the community pool. I noticed a commotion—someone was in the deep end, flailing, clearly struggling. As a lifeguard, I knew the rules: no one was allowed in the deep end without supervision, and I was trained to act fast in emergencies. But as a sibling, my parents always told me to never leave my brother alone, especially near busy streets. He looked up at me, eyes wide, sensing my urgency. I could see the expectation in his face—he trusted me to keep him safe. At the same time, my lifeguard instincts screamed at me to enforce the rules and help the struggling child. My heart pounded as I stood frozen, torn between my duty to my brother and my responsibility as a lifeguard. I could feel the weight of both roles pressing down on me, each demanding something I wasn’t sure I could give at the same time.
